learning_outcomes.description: Understand the commercial publishing process from acquisition of a manuscript to final proofreading.
Understand and apply conventions of structural editing.
Understand and apply conventions of copyediting and proofreading.
Develop skills in conveying assessments and advice to authors and industry professionals.
Develop basic skills in using contemporary desktop publishing software.

assessments.task_description:
In this task, students will complete a combined copyediting and proofreading exercise using a printed text (either a short story or non-fiction article). The exam will be completed during class time and is open book; students may refer to notes and reference materials, but only in printed form: no digital devices are permitted.

Copyediting Component

Students will copyedit the text to improve clarity, consistency, and style. This includes refining sentence structure, enhancing tone and readability, ensuring consistency in spelling, punctuation, and formatting, and making stylistic improvements appropriate to the intended audience.

Edits should be annotated directly on the text. Students must also submit a brief rationale (2–3 sentences) explaining key editorial decisions and a completed style sheet (template provided) outlining stylistic choices made during the edit.

Proofreading Component

Students will identify and correct hard errors in the same text. These may include spelling, punctuation, grammar, formatting, and typographical issues.

Corrections must be made using standard proofreading symbols, as discussed in tutorials. A reference sheet of proofreading marks will be provided during the exam.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
You are required to attend at least one session at the Brisbane Writers Festival and submit a short written reflection (maximum 500 words) on your experience. Your reflection should go beyond summarising the session and instead explore your personal and critical response to the ideas presented. Consider how the session relates to your studies in editing and publishing, what insights it offered into the literary or publishing industries, and how it may have influenced your thinking as a future editor or publishing professional.

Your response should be thoughtful, clearly written, and demonstrate engagement with the event. You are encouraged to take notes during the session to support your reflection.

A completed cover sheet with a Declaration and Acknowledgment of AI Use must be submitted with your reflection.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
For this assignment, you will read one novel from the list of debut Australian titles provided on Blackboard (see the folder in the Assessment section). You will take on the role of an editor who has just read the manuscript and is preparing to present it at an acquisitions meeting. Your task is to write a persuasive publishing proposal (800–1000 words) using the acquisitions proposal proforma provided on Blackboard, which is based on documentation used by a major Sydney-based publisher.

In addition to the written component (worth 25%), you will participate in an in-class acquisitions meeting (worth 15%) during the lecture and tutorial in Week 12 and the tutorial in week 13, where you will pitch your book to the class, respond to questions about your proposal, and engage in discussion by asking thoughtful questions of your peers. Attendance at both acquisitions meeting tutorials is required, even if you are not presenting that week as being an active participant in the discussion and questions will be assessed as part of this assignment. The written proposal must be submitted to Turnitin after the second acquisitions meeting, and must include a completed cover sheet with a Declaration and Acknowledgment of AI Use, as per course requirements.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit the proposal after the meeting via TurnItIn through Blackboard
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
For this assignment, you will choose one of the full-length manuscripts available on Blackboard to print out and work on throughout the semester.

Your task is to write a structural editing report of 3000–3500 words, offering clear, constructive, and comprehensive feedback to the author. While you may decide on the overall structure and format of your report, it should reflect your editorial judgement and the specific needs of the manuscript you’ve selected. Your report should identify both strengths and weaknesses, provide specific suggestions where appropriate, and maintain a supportive and professional tone throughout. High-quality reports are typically thoughtful, consistent, and genuinely helpful to the author. You are expected to express yourself clearly, and your report should be carefully proofread and mechanically flawless. To guide your approach, you are encouraged to review and grade one or more of the sample structural reports available on Blackboard using the provided criteria sheet—consider where you can improve and what best practices you can adopt in your own work. A completed cover sheet with a Declaration and Acknowledgment of AI Use must be submitted with your assignment.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.
